questions.question: A bag contains <math><mn>5</mn></math> red marbles, <math><mn>3</mn></math> blue marbles, and <math><mn>2</mn></math> green marbles. If one marble is selected at random from the bag, what is the probability that the marble is blue?
questions.explanation: The total number of marbles is <math><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. The number of favorable outcomes (blue marbles) is <math><mn>3</mn></math>. The probability is <math><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Probability is the ratio of favorable outcomes to the total number of possible outcomes.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='220' viewBox='0 0 400 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><style>text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; }</style><rect width='100%' height='100%' fill='white'/><rect x='20' y='20' width='360' height='180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='110' x2='380' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='20' x2='290' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='65' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Grade</text><text x='155' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Bus</text><text x='245' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Walk</text><text x='335' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='65' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>9th</text><text x='155' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>40</text><text x='245' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>10</text><text x='335' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>50</text><text x='65' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>10th</text><text x='155' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>30</text><text x='245' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>20</text><text x='335' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>50</text><text x='65' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='155' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>70</text><text x='245' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>30</text><text x='335' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>100</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A table showing transportation data. Rows: 9th, 10th, Total. Columns: Bus, Walk, Total. 9th Graders: 40 Bus, 10 Walk. 10th Graders: 30 Bus, 20 Walk. Totals: 70 Bus, 30 Walk, 100 Grand Total.
questions.question: The table above shows the distribution of 9th and 10th-grade students based on how they get to school. If a student is selected at random from the group, what is the probability that the student takes the bus?
questions.explanation:
To find the probability, divide the number of favorable outcomes by the total number of outcomes.

1. **Favorable Outcomes:** Look at the 'Bus' column total. There are 70 students who take the bus.
2. **Total Outcomes:** Look at the 'Total' column bottom row. There are 100 students in total.

Probability = 70100=0.7.

questions.explanation_chart_description: The same table with two circles: a red circle around the number 70 (Total Bus riders) labeled 'Favorable', and a blue circle around the number 100 (Grand Total) labeled 'Total'.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the 'favorable' group (Bus) and the 'total' group (All students) from the table margins to set up your fraction.

questions.question: A number is chosen at random from the set <math><mo>{</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>...</mo><mo>,</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>}</mo></math>. What is the probability that the number chosen is a multiple of <math><mn>5</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The multiples of <math><mn>5</mn></math> in the set are <math><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>20</mn></math>. There are <math><mn>4</mn></math> favorable outcomes. The total number of outcomes is <math><mn>20</mn></math>. <math><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>20</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: List the outcomes that satisfy the condition to ensure an accurate count.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='220' viewBox='0 0 400 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><style>text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; }</style><rect width='100%' height='100%' fill='white'/><rect x='20' y='20' width='360' height='180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='110' x2='380' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='20' x2='290' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='65' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Preference</text><text x='155' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Action</text><text x='245' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Comedy</text><text x='335' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='65' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>Group A</text><text x='155' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>45</text><text x='245' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>15</text><text x='335' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>60</text><text x='65' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>Group B</text><text x='155' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>25</text><text x='245' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>35</text><text x='335' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>60</text><text x='65' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='155' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>70</text><text x='245' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>50</text><text x='335' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>120</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A contingency table comparing movie preferences. Group A: 45 prefer Action, 15 Comedy. Group B: 25 prefer Action, 35 Comedy. The Total Action count is 70.
questions.question: The table above shows the movie preferences for two groups of people. If a person is selected at random from those who prefer Action movies, what is the probability that the person is from Group A?
questions.explanation:
This is a conditional probability question. The condition 'from those who prefer Action movies' restricts our total to the **Action** column.

1. **Denominator (Total Condition):** The total number of people who prefer Action is 70.
2. **Numerator (Target Group):** Among these 70 people, 45 are from Group A.

Probability = 4570. Dividing numerator and denominator by 5 gives 914.

stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' questions.explanation_chart_description: The table with the 'Action' column highlighted in yellow. The cell '45' is marked as the Numerator (Target) and '70' is marked as the Denominator (Condition).
questions.score_improvement_tip: For conditional probability P(A|B), the denominator is the total count of the condition group B (in this case, the 'Action' column total).

questions.question: Two independent events, A and B, have probabilities <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn></math> and <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn></math>. What is the probability that both events occur?
questions.explanation: Since A and B are independent, <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mtext> and </mtext><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>×</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.6</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.30</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If events are independent, multiply their probabilities to find the probability of both happening.

questions.question: In a survey of <math><mn>200</mn></math> people, <math><mn>120</mn></math> like tea, <math><mn>80</mn></math> like coffee, and <math><mn>40</mn></math> like both. If a person is selected at random, what is the probability that they like tea or coffee?
questions.explanation: Use the formula <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>∪</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Number liking T or C is <math><mn>120</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>160</mn></math>. Probability is <math><mfrac><mn>160</mn><mn>200</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Subtract the intersection (both) to avoid double counting when finding the union (or).

questions.question: A spinner is divided into <math><mn>8</mn></math> equal sections numbered <math><mn>1</mn></math> through <math><mn>8</mn></math>. What is the probability of spinning a number that is either prime or even?
questions.explanation: Primes: <math><mo>{</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>}</mo></math>. Evens: <math><mo>{</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>}</mo></math>. Union: <math><mo>{</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>}</mo></math>. Note <math><mn>2</mn></math> is in both, but listed once in the set. There are <math><mn>7</mn></math> unique numbers. <math><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: List the outcomes for each condition and combine them, ensuring no duplicates.

questions.question: A bag contains <math><mi>x</mi></math> green marbles and <math><mn>5</mn></math> yellow marbles. If the probability of drawing a green marble is <math><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.score_improvement_tip: Set up an equation where probability equals favorable over total, then solve for the unknown.

questions.question: A survey of <math><mn>50</mn></math> people found that <math><mn>30</mn></math> own a dog, <math><mn>20</mn></math> own a cat, and <math><mn>12</mn></math> own both. If a person is selected at random from those who own a dog, what is the probability that they also own a cat? (Express your answer as a decimal)
questions.explanation: Condition: Own a dog (Total = <math><mn>30</mn></math>). Favorable: Own both (Total = <math><mn>12</mn></math>). <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mtext>Cat</mtext><mo>|</mo><mtext>Dog</mtext><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>12</mn><mn>30</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the subset defined by the 'given' condition.

questions.question: Events A and B are such that <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn></math>, <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn></math>, and <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∪</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.7</mn></math>. Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Events A and B are independent.
options.B: Events A and B are mutually exclusive.
options.C: Events A and B are neither independent nor mutually exclusive.
options.D: Events A and B are both independent and mutually exclusive.

questions.explanation: First find <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∪</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. <math><mn>0.7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, so <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn></math>. Now check independence: <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn></math>. Since <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>∩</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>)</mo><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, they are independent.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check independence by verifying if P(A and B) equals P(A) * P(B).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='250' height='250' viewBox='0 0 250 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='250' height='250' fill='white'/><circle cx='125' cy='125' r='90' fill='white' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='125' cy='125' r='60' fill='#f0f0f0' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><circle cx='125' cy='125' r='30' fill='gray' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='125' y1='125' x2='215' y2='125' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='155' y1='122' x2='155' y2='128' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='140' y='120' font-family='Arial' font-size='10'>3</text><line x1='185' y1='122' x2='185' y2='128' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='170' y='120' font-family='Arial' font-size='10'>6</text><text x='200' y='120' font-family='Arial' font-size='10'>9</text><circle cx='125' cy='125' r='2' fill='black'/></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A target with three concentric circles. The innermost circle is shaded gray. A radius line indicates the radii of the three circles are 3, 6, and 9 units respectively.
questions.question: A dart hits the circular target shown above at a random point. The radii of the three concentric circles are <math><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mn>6</mn></math>, and <math><mn>9</mn></math>. What is the probability that the dart lands in the gray region (the smallest circle)?
questions.explanation:
Geometric probability is the ratio of the favorable area to the total area.

1. **Total Area:** The target has a total radius of 9.
Area = πr2=π(92)=81π.
2. **Favorable Area:** The gray region has a radius of 3.
Area = πr2=π(32)=9π.
3. **Probability:** 9π81π=981=19.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='250' height='250' viewBox='0 0 250 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='250' height='250' fill='white'/><circle cx='125' cy='125' r='90' fill='#e3f2fd' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5'/><circle cx='125' cy='125' r='30' fill='#4caf50' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='125' y1='125' x2='148' y2='148' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='150' y='160' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' fill='#2e7d32' font-weight='bold'>Favorable: 9π</text><line x1='125' y1='35' x2='125' y2='10' stroke='blue' stroke-width='1'/><text x='125' y='20' font-family='Arial' font-size='12' fill='blue' text-anchor='middle'>Total Area: 81π</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The target with the outermost boundary highlighted in dashed blue (Total Area) and the innermost circle highlighted in green (Favorable Area).
questions.score_improvement_tip: For geometric probability, calculate the Area of the Favorable Region divided by the Total Area.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='220' viewBox='0 0 400 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><style>text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; }</style><rect width='100%' height='100%' fill='white'/><rect x='20' y='20' width='360' height='180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='110' x2='380' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='20' x2='290' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='65' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Region</text><text x='155' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Option 1</text><text x='245' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Option 2</text><text x='335' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='65' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>North</text><text x='155' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>120</text><text x='245' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>80</text><text x='335' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>200</text><text x='65' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>South</text><text x='155' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>180</text><text x='245' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>120</text><text x='335' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>300</text><text x='65' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='155' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>300</text><text x='245' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>200</text><text x='335' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>500</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A contingency table comparing voting preferences by region. North Region: 120 for Option 1, 80 for Option 2 (Total 200). South Region: 180 for Option 1, 120 for Option 2 (Total 300). Grand Total: 500.
questions.question: The table above shows the distribution of voters in two regions. Based on the data, which of the following statements is true about the events 'selecting a voter from the North region' and 'selecting a voter who prefers Option 1'?

options.C: The events are not independent because <math><mn>0.6</mn><mo>≠</mo><mn>0.4</mn></math>.
options.D: The events are not independent because <math><mn>0.6</mn><mo>≠</mo><mn>0.24</mn></math>.

questions.explanation:
Events A and B are **independent** if the probability of A occurring is the same whether or not B has occurred ($P(A|B) = P(A)$).

1. **Marginal Probability:** Probability of selecting Option 1 overall.
$P(\text{Option 1}) = \frac{300}{500} = 0.6$
2. **Conditional Probability:** Probability of selecting Option 1 given the voter is from the North.
$P(\text{Option 1} | \text{North}) = \frac{120}{200} = 0.6$

Since $0.6 = 0.6$, the preference for Option 1 is not affected by the region. Therefore, the events are independent.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='220' viewBox='0 0 400 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><style>text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; }</style><rect width='100%' height='100%' fill='white'/><rect x='20' y='65' width='360' height='45' fill='#e3f2fd' stroke='none'/><rect x='20' y='155' width='360' height='45' fill='#fce4ec' stroke='none'/><rect x='20' y='20' width='360' height='180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='110' x2='380' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='20' x2='290' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='65' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Region</text><text x='155' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Option 1</text><text x='335' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='65' y='95' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>North</text><text x='155' y='95' text-anchor='middle' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>120</text><text x='245' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>80</text><text x='335' y='95' text-anchor='middle' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>200</text><text x='65' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>South</text><text x='155' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>180</text><text x='245' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>120</text><text x='335' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>300</text><text x='65' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='155' y='185' text-anchor='middle' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>300</text><text x='245' y='185' text-anchor='middle'>200</text><text x='335' y='185' text-anchor='middle' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>500</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The table with the 'North' row highlighted in blue and the 'Total' row highlighted in pink. The ratios 120/200 and 300/500 are calculated next to the rows, showing both equal 0.6.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check for independence by comparing the conditional probability of an event (e.g., in one row) to its overall marginal probability (Total row). If they are equal, the events are independent.

questions.question: A weighted coin has a probability of <math><mn>0.4</mn></math> of landing on heads. If the coin is flipped <math><mn>3</mn></math> times, what is the probability of getting at least one head?
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'at least one' problems, calculate 1 minus the probability of 'none'.

questions.question: In a certain population, <math><mn>1</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of people have a specific disease. A test for the disease is <math><mn>90</mn><mo>%</mo></math> accurate for those who have the disease (True Positive) and <math><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></math> accurate for those who do not (True Negative). If a person tests positive, what is the approximate probability that they actually have the disease?
questions.explanation:
Assume 1000 people. Disease: 10 people. No Disease: 990.
Positives: 0.9×10=9 (True Pos). 0.05×990=49.5 (False Pos). Total Pos = 58.5. P(Disease|Pos)=958.5≈0.15.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use a hypothetical population (e.g., 1000) to build a contingency table for these types of problems.

questions.question: A jar contains <math><mn>6</mn></math> red marbles and <math><mi>k</mi></math> blue marbles. If the probability of drawing two red marbles in a row without replacement is <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'without replacement' problems, remember to decrease the numerator and denominator for the second event.

questions.question: There are <math><mn>5</mn></math> people in a room. If each person is assigned a random day of the week (Monday through Sunday) for a meeting, what is the probability that all <math><mn>5</mn></math> people are assigned to different days? (Round your answer to the nearest thousandth)
questions.explanation: Total possibilities: <math><msup><mn>7</mn><mn>5</mn></msup></math>. Favorable: <math><mn>7</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. <math><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2520</mn><mn>16807</mn></mfrac><mo>≈</mo><mn>0.1499</mn></math>. Rounding to the nearest thousandth gives <math><mn>0.150</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'all different', use permutations for the numerator and exponents for the denominator.

questions.question: A system consists of two components, A and B. Component A has a <math><mn>0.9</mn></math> probability of working, and Component B has a <math><mn>0.8</mn></math> probability of working. The components work independently. What is the probability that exactly one of the components works?
questions.score_improvement_tip: Break down complex events into mutually exclusive cases (e.g., A works/B fails OR A fails/B works).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='220' viewBox='0 0 400 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><style>text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; }</style><rect width='100%' height='100%' fill='white'/><rect x='20' y='20' width='360' height='180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='20' y1='110' x2='380' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='20' x2='290' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='65' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Age</text><text x='155' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Yes</text><text x='245' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>No</text><text x='335' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='65' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>18-25</text><text x='155' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>40</text><text x='245' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>60</text><text x='335' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>100</text><text x='65' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>26-35</text><text x='155' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>70</text><text x='245' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>30</text><text x='335' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>100</text><text x='65' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='155' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>110</text><text x='245' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>90</text><text x='335' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>200</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A contingency table showing survey results. Rows: Age Groups 18-25 and 26-35. Columns: Response Yes and No. 18-25: 40 Yes, 60 No. 26-35: 70 Yes, 30 No. Total No responses is 90.
questions.question: The table above shows the responses to a survey about voting intent. If a respondent is chosen at random, what is the probability that they are in the 18-25 age group, given that they answered 'No'?
questions.explanation:
This is a conditional probability question. The condition 'given that they answered No' restricts our focus to the **No** column.

1. **Denominator (Total Condition):** The total number of people who answered 'No' is 90.
2. **Numerator (Target Group):** Among those 90 people, the number in the 18-25 age group is 60.

Probability = 6090. Simplifying the fraction gives 23.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='220' viewBox='0 0 400 220' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><style>text { font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; }</style><rect width='100%' height='100%' fill='white'/><rect x='200' y='20' width='90' height='180' fill='#fff9c4' stroke='none'/><rect x='20' y='20' width='360' height='180' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='65' x2='380' y2='65' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='20' y1='155' x2='380' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='110' y1='20' x2='110' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='20' x2='290' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='65' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Age</text><text x='155' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Yes</text><text x='245' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>No</text><text x='335' y='50' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='65' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>18-25</text><text x='155' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>40</text><text x='245' y='95' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#d32f2f'>60</text><text x='335' y='95' text-anchor='middle'>100</text><text x='65' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>26-35</text><text x='155' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>70</text><text x='245' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>30</text><text x='335' y='140' text-anchor='middle'>100</text><text x='65' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>Total</text><text x='155' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>110</text><text x='245' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold' fill='#1976d2'>90</text><text x='335' y='185' text-anchor='middle' font-weight='bold'>200</text><rect x='215' y='80' width='60' height='30' fill='none' stroke='#d32f2f' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='4,2'/></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The table with the 'No' column highlighted. The number 60 (18-25) is circled in red as the Numerator, and 90 (Total No) is circled in blue as the Denominator.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the total for the 'given' condition first (denominator), then find the intersection (numerator).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='200' height='200' viewBox='0 0 200 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><circle cx='100' cy='100' r='80' fill='white' stroke='black'/><path d='M100,100 L180,100 A80,80 0 0,0 100,20 Z' fill='gray' stroke='black'/><text x='110' y='90'>90°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with a shaded sector. The central angle of the sector is 90 degrees.
questions.question: A point is selected at random inside the circle shown above. If the shaded sector has a central angle of <math><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the probability that the selected point lies in the shaded region?
questions.explanation: The probability is the ratio of the sector's area to the circle's area, which is the same as the ratio of the central angle to <math><mn>360</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. <math><mfrac><mn>90</mn><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For geometric probability involving circles, use the ratio of angles: Angle / 360.
